Labs.title: Spatial Cognition Lab
Labs.description: The first research lab I worked in was the Spatial Cognition Lab at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. I worked primarily under the graduate student Meera Zukosky. I was working on a “mind-wandering” project. The purpose of the study was to determine approximately how long a person can focus on a cognitive task before their mind wanders elsewhere and their attention is broken. I was one of the two research assistants that ran participants through the experiment and recorded the results. I was only a part of this project for one semester, and it was in the middle of the experiment process. I cannot speak to the conclusions made from the work, as I moved to another lab long before the experiment was ended.

Labs.title: Center for Parent-Child Studies
Labs.description: The second lab I worked in was the Center for Parent-Child Studies. I worked primarily under graduate student Janet Ng. I was a part of the Reasoning Skills Project. The purpose of the study was to determine differences in the parenting styles between American parents and Eastern-Asian parents (we worked with a sister lab in Hong Kong, China). I oversaw running the child in the experiment, recording the results, data entry, and transcribing and analyzing the videos of the mothers. Again, I left before the project ended, so I cannot relay the specific findings from the study (it is currently ongoing). However, the consensus was that American parents were much more focused on their child’s self-worth and making sure they weren’t upset, whereas the Asian parents focused more on their children improving on the task.

Labs.title: Decision Neuroscience Lab
Labs.description: The third lab I contributed to at UIUC was the Decision Neuroscience Lab at the renowned Beckman Institute for Advanced Science and Technology. I worked under the supervision of a post-doc, Chris Zwilling. I was a part of two projects in the lab: a Cognitive Chronobiology study and a Nutritional Cognitive Enhancement study. I was the sole undergraduate research assistant working on the Cognitive Chronobiology study, and will be credited as a co-author on the paper when it is published. I wrote the data analysis for both of these projects in R, a statistical computing scripting language. In addition to the data analysis, I created multiple graphs and spreadsheets for the director's use when presenting the project to financiers and journal editors.
